utterance: Mark Mimee: Hello. Uh my name is Mark Mimee. I'm an assistant professor at the University of Chicago in both the Department of Microbiology and the School of Molecular Engineering. Um, and essentially our group is uh if you will, a microbiome engineering group. So I was trained as a synthetic biologist, so we're really interested in developing tools to be able to modulate the microbiome. Um, and there's kind of two camps in the lab. The first camp works on uh cellular engineering, so doing genetic engineering and uh gut commensals, um, and sort of not just model organisms, but trying to break into non-model organisms as well. And then the second half of the lab works on bacteria phages as sort of very narrow spectrum antimicrobials that could be used to remove uh sort of bad players from the microbiome.

utterance: Linnea Freeman: I'll jump in and start a little discussion maybe, I don't know. Um I can only speak from what my experiments have told me, but um and obviously this is within mice, so I'm I would love to hear other ideas and input. Um just from my research and from um you know, literature searches, one main aspect here is that um what your microbiome is is kind of stuck in a sense and I think that kind of connects with the presentation that we just listened to that um there's only so much that I can see right now that really can change the microbiome all that much. So the research I do is on diet and we can definitely perturb the microbiome with um high fat, high sugar because obviously that's going to change the um microorganisms that are going to feed on that sugar and saturated fat. But I I am fascinated by the fact that we do see differences between males and females and those seem to be pretty consistent within those groups. Um and then there's certainly the impact of um birth and early exposure and how that kind of just sets you up for life with what your microbiome stays as.

annotations.present new idea: Linnea introduces the idea that the microbiome is relatively stable and difficult to change significantly, connecting it to a previous presentation and her own research.
annotations.provide supporting evidence: Linnea supports her idea about the microbiome's stability by referencing her research on diet in mice, literature searches, and observed differences between males and females, as well as the impact of early life exposure.
annotations.expand on existing idea: Linnea expands on the idea of microbiome stability by providing specific examples from her research on diet, mentioning how high fat and high sugar diets can perturb the microbiome, and highlighting the consistent differences observed between males and females.

utterance: Linnea Freeman: Um and the last just thought from triggered from these um comments is I do use antibiotics to cause severe dysbiosis and then try to see what's happening in the brain because of that. And um in that case, antibiotics do have a huge impact and we give them in the drinking water for for mice for six weeks, so they're constantly getting antibiotics, but if I think about um, you know, for my kids or something with ear infections and all the antibiotics they've been taking, it's just amazing to think about how static our microbiome can be in general and then those early life exposures to many rounds of antibiotics and how much that can perturb the system.

annotations.provide supporting evidence: Linnea supports her point about the impact of antibiotics on the microbiome by describing her experiment where she uses antibiotics to cause dysbiosis in mice and observes the effects on the brain, and she also mentions the potential impact of early life antibiotic exposure on children's microbiomes.
